awd_abstract_narration:
The modern mathematical study of infinity began in the period 1879-84 with a series of papers by Cantor that defined the fundamental framework of the subject. Within 40 years the key principles of Set Theory were discovered, these are the ZFC axioms, and the stage was set for the detailed development of transfinite mathematics, or so it seemed. However, in a completely unexpected development, Cohen showed in 1963 that even the most basic problem of Set Theory was not solvable on the basis of these principles alone. That problem was the widely discussed and celebrated problem of Cantor's Continuum Hypothesis. The 50 years since Cohen's announcement has seen a vast development of Cohen's method and to the realization that the occurrence of unsolvable problems is ubiquitous in Set Theory. This arguably challenges the very conception of Cantor on which Set Theory is based. However, during this same period, the detailed study of special cases of the Continuum Hypothesis led to a remarkable success. This was the discovery and validation of a key new principle for Second Order Number Theory. Second Order Number Theory is the study of the structure of all sets of counting numbers, and this is just Set Theory in its simplest incarnation. The resulting theory is largely immune to Cohen's method. The prospect that this could somehow be extended to produce an analogous new principle for Set Theory itself (as a single additional axiom to the ZFC axioms) has always seemed completely hopeless. But that belief was itself based on a misconception and recent discoveries suggest there is a resolution. These discoveries were the result of prior NSF supported research. This project continues and expands the research based on these discoveries.

Gödel's consistency proof for the Axiom of Choice and the Continuum Hypothesis involves his discovery of the Constructible Universe of Sets. The axiom "V = L" is the axiom which asserts that every set is constructible. This axiom settles the Continuum Hypothesis and more importantly,  Cohen's method of forcing  cannot be used in the context of the axiom "V = L". However the axiom V = L is  false since it limits the fundamental nature of infinity. In particular the axiom refutes (most) strong axioms of infinity. A key question emerges. Is there an "ultimate" version of Gödel's constructible universe L yielding an axiom "V = Ultimate L" which retains the power of the axiom "V = L"  for resolving questions like that of the Continuum Hypothesis, which is also immune against Cohen's method of forcing, and yet which does not refute strong axioms of infinity? This vague question has been recast, through previously supported research,  into a specific and precise conjecture; the Ultimate L Conjecture. The goal of this project is to resolve that conjecture.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: PRESIDENT AND FELLOWS OF HARVARD COLLEGE

por.por_cntn:
Set Theory is the area of Mathematics focused on the study of Infinity. One of the most fundamental problems of Set Theory is that of Cantor's Continuum Hypotheses (CH). Set Theory began with Cantor's discovery of the different sizes of Infinity and his proof that the infinite size of the set of all real numbers, is not the smallest infinity (which is the size of the counting numbers). The question then is whether the infinity of the real numbers is the next largest infinity, and Cantor's Continuum Hypothesis is the formal assertion that it is.
The results of Godel from 1940 and the results of Cohen from 1964, showed that CH can be neither proved or refuted on the basis of the accepted ZFC axioms of Set Theory. Thus the formal axioms ZFC do not give sufficient insight into the nature of the Universe of Sets (V). This has led to the program of finding the missing additional axioms. One initially promising axiom was Godel's axiom V = L. This axiom is immune to Cohen's method forcing and (as Godel showed) this axiom implies that CH is true. However by Scott's theorem of 60 years ago, Axioms of Infinity refute the axiom V = L, and so this axiom must be rejected.
The program of finding generalizations of the axiom V = L has been a major program within Set Theory for 50 years, however it was widely accepted that every for every generalization, there would also be a corresponding generalization of Scott's theorem which then forces one to reject that generalization as a new axiom for V. This program was seen not so much as a program of finding new axioms, but simply understanding more deeply Axioms of Infinity.
This however was based on a misconception and now there is a specific ultimate generalization, this is the axiom V = Ultimate L, first formulated around 10 years ago but then revised because of the outcomes of this project (the outcomes having revealed that the orginal formulation is in fact likely refuted by Axioms of Infinity).  Among the other outcomes of this project is that the (revised) axiom V = Ultimate L, is also both immune to Cohen's method and implies CH. The revison of the axiom superficially seems minor, but it represents a fundamental conceptual shift. Proving that the revised axiom is immune ot Cohen's method required obtaining new results in AD+ Theory, which is another major area in Set Theory.
The critical question is whether Scott's theorem generalizes to this new axiom, and in particular whether Axioms of Infinity also refute the axiom V = Ultimate L. But here there is a specific conjecture, this is the Ultimate L Conjecture, which if true shows that no Axiom of Infinity (which is not itself contradictory) can refute V = Ultimate L, and moreover this applies to a very general abstract notion of what an Axiom of Infinity is.
The Ultimate L Conjecture must be true or false (it cannot be meaningless). If it is true then one has at the very least a serious candidate for the one missing axiom which is both immune to Cohen's method and which is compatible with all Axioms of Infinity. If it is false then the program to find the missing axioms for Set Theory through generalizing Godel's axiom V = L arguably fails, and an entirely different approach to new axioms is needed. Thus Set Theory has come to a critical juncture.
The focus of this project was the Ultimate L Conjecture, first in the context of the original formulation of the axiom V = Ultimate L, and then in the context of the revised (and final) form of this axiom. The discoveries have yielded a much clearer understanding of the conjecture and have shown that it is connected to many other problems in Set Theory. In summary on the basis of the outcomes of this project, there is arguably a clear path forward to settle the matter once and for all, by either proving the Ultimate L Conjecture, or by refuting it. 


Last Modified: 09/28/2021
Modified by: W. Hugh Woodin
